Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Title: HOUSING INTEREST RATES
text: I direct a question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What action has the Australian Government taken to follow up allegations of child labour in the Philippines, contained in a report on Channel 9's Sunday program in November 1985? What results, if any, have been obtained?

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: HOUSING INTEREST RATES
text: The honourable member for Sydney raised the question of child labour in the Philippines on 19 November in this House. His question followed a report on Channel 9's Sunday program, which depicted the large scale use of child labour in the Philippines fishing industry. The Australian Embassy in Manila carried out investigations into the allegations raised in the program following the issue being raised in the Parliament by the honourable member for Sydney. Embassy officials raised the matter with officials of the Ministry of Labour and Employment, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and the International Labour Organisation. Officials also talked to the American broadcasting company who made the program, the crew of the research vessel Soli, and a local member of parliament. Following questions raised by Australian Embassy officials, the ILO has given funds to the Ministry of Labour and Employment to start an investigation into the alleged practices shown in the report. The ILO is currently finalising a report on child labour in the Philippines. The Embassy in Manila will continue to liaise with the ILO on the results of its investigations. I congratulate the honourable member for Sydney for having raised this matter in the Parliament and similarly congratulate the Sunday program on Channel 9, which brought the matter before public attention in the first instance. As a result of that conjunction of initiatives, action is now being taken on this matter. I hope that the final result will lead to an amelioration of the working conditions for children in the Philippines. NA

text: Order! I have listened with interest to what the honourable member for O'Connor raised in the House tonight. Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Title: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION
text: I wish to make the. point very seriously that when a matter of thi.s importance is raised, the Government owes It to the people of Australia, particularly those who are suffering from the Government's high interest rate policies, to have the Ministers responsible here in the chamber to answer. If the Government is not prepared to do that, the Opposition will take the appropriate action to ensure that it does so in the future. Also, I might point out that there is not one single Australian Labor Party member present in the chamber other than the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. There is not a single Labor member other than this junior Minister here to debate a matter of very considerable importance. It is all very well for the Labor Party to get itself into a lather in Caucus this morning about this matter because members are unhappy about .the decision made by the Government, yet not one single Labor member,. apart from the duty junior Minister, has come here to answer the case. Everyone in Australia who is listening to this debate should understand that fact. Over the weekend I spoke to a young man who has a wife and a baby daughter and who bought a home on the western outskirts of Sydney about 12 months ago. The young couple worked out their budget very carefully. The wife had had to give up work in order to look after the newly arrived baby. The husband had calculated that, by taking on extra overtime in his job and by cutting back household expenditures to the bare minimum, the family could just afford the monthly repayments of something over $600 on a building society loan. That was round about the time of the last Federal election when building societies were charging 13 per cent interest on their. loans and that is not a small figure. Thirteen per cent is a lot of money. The young couple felt perfectly confident about their plans and their purchase. 'After all, they had the assurance of the Prime Minister of Australia that the Government placed homes for young people at the top .of its priorities. The Prime Minister, in his 1983 policy speech, said: To provide a stable and adequate flow of funds for housing at affordable interest rates, the Labor Government will maintain interest rate controls on b'ank mortgage intere-t rates and extend those controls to building societies. That was the promise of the Prime Minister in 1983. Our young couple would not have seen the inherent contradiction in that statement. They would not have known that,if interest rates rose above the controlled levels, the flow of funds would dry up. But they trusted the Prime Minister. TheY also trusted him when he repeated his commitment in his 1984 policy speech in these words: We pledged ourselves to bring home ownership within the reach' of ordinary Australian families-to end that sense of despair and frustration that was beginning to engulf thousands upon thousands of young people seeking their own homes. Those were the confident words of the Prime Minister seeking re-election only 16 months ago and they would indeed have been reassuring to our young couple embarking on the most important financial decision of their lives which, of course, was buying their own home. The Prime Minister was also categorical about interest rates. In the course of a major address in Adelaide on 20 November 1984, as the election campaign was drawing to a close, the Prime Minister said: At present the outlook for interest rates is as it has been for more than a decade. Mr Donald Cameron----:Who said that?

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Title: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION
text: The Prime Minister in the 1984 election campaign only 16 months ago. Mr Donald Cameron-That is not a long time ago.

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Title: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION
text: As the honourable member for Moreton quite correctly points out, it is not a very long time since that was said. The Prime Minister said: We will continue our work of putting the public finances of this nation back in order and creating the conditions where further interest rate reductions can occur. The Prime Minister was backed up by this Treasurer who, in a Press release of 15 November 1984, declared: Continued success against inflation will conditions conducive to lower interest rates. Unfortunately for that young couple I spoke about, the election was not long over when interest rates began to rise. Indeed, they were worried that even by the time they had completed the settlement on their home they would already by paying over $40 a month in additional repayments because the building society interest rates had gone up and they have gone up yet again to 14t per cent since then adding $60 a month to the· initial monthly repayment which was the basis of their careful calculatiollS. At this time their budget has been stretched to the very limit and it has not been helped by the husband-s wages going into higher tax brackets with overtime and the general rise in prices over recent months. With an inflation rate of over 8 per cent all Australian families, and particulatly those on low incomes, are feeling the pinch.

Speaker: Mr GOODLUCK
Title: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION
text: They are battling.

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Title: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION
text: As my friend the honourable member for Franklin has said, they are battling. He is known as the little battler and he would know that these people are really feeling the pinch. So honourable members can imagine the extreme nervousness of this· family feeling trapped by the situation but managing at this stage to cling on by its fingernails. Meanwhile, a stream of reassuring statements has been emerging from Government Ministers. On 17 October last year in this House the Minister for Housing and Construction said: Let me say quite firmly again, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said several times in the House, that we do not intend to deregulate housing interest rates, at this time. It is completely the wrong time to do so. We do not intend as bright to lift the ceiling from 13t per cent. On 14 November 1985 the Treasurer appeared on AM and we had the following exchange: Question: You are still insisting are you that the 13.5 per cent ceiling on home loan interest rates should be maintained? Keating: Yes I am. Question: And there's no possibility of changing that in the foreseeable future? Keating: No. Then there was a whole string of announcements and reassurances from the Treasurer, the Prime Minister and the hapless Minister for Housing and Construction, culminating in the solemn assurances given in this House in response to Opposition questioning just over two weeks ago, on 19 March. The Minister for Housing and Construction declared: create The Government remains committed to the retention of the ceiling on housing interest rates. The Prime Minister, only two weeks before the fateful announcement which reversed yet another policy and broke yet another promise, said: I say to the Leader of the Opposition that the Government will be considering the whole question of the housing industry in Cabinet next week and I say to him, as the Minister for Housing and Construction did, that the Government remains committed to the retention of the ceiling on housing interest rates. It is a pity that there is no member of the Press Gallery other than the Australian Associated Press here to witness this debate, where the Treasurer is absent and not meeting his responsibility to answer these charges.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION
text: Where is he?

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Title: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION
text: Where indeed is the Treasurer and where is the Press Gallery to watch this debate? We might forgive our young couple clihging to their home on the outskirts of Sydney for starting to have some doubts as to the strength of the Prime Minister's commitment. The Treasurer appeared to be equivocal the following day on the steps of Parliament House, but at Question Time he too repeated this commitment. What happened just two weeks later, on 2 April? The Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Housing and Construction announced that the ceiling would be lifted for new savings bank loans, a subsidy would be provided to the banks, and the banks only, so that existing savings bank loans could be maintained at 13-1per cent, but that essentially existing building society borrowers could be thrown to the wolves. The young man 1 spoke to on Saturday was aghast at this decision. He simply could not alford to meet the weekly repayments at a higher rate. Building societies were saying that to meet the additional competition for deposits from the savings banks following the Government's subsidy to the savings banks they would have to raise their deposit and lending rates. Existing building society loans would rise to 15.5 per cent interest. On a $55,000 loan-not uncommon in Sydney for even a modest home-a rate of 1St would mean an additional monthly cost of $96 in interest charges since the last election only 16 months ago and since the Prime Minister promised that interest rates would not rise. My young couple simply cannot alford that. They are desperately worried that they will have to sen their home and are frightened that so many others will be doing the same and that in the price drop they will lose the value of their initial deposit and hence their whole life savings. An they have worked for is suddenly disappearing before their eyes. They feel cheated, disbelieving and angry. What answer can the Prime Minister give this young couple? How can they possibly believe ever again a solemn promise from the Prime Minister? The fact is that Hawke promises are worthless promises, broken promises-on interest rates, on taxes, on the trilogy, on petrol prices, on the assets test, on the tax on lump sum superannuation payments, on the value of the Australian dollar, on the 10,000 traineeships under the Priority One scheme; you name the promise, the Prime Minister has broken it. I am not alone in reflecting the feeling of betrayal amongst so many Australian families. The honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) is quoted in today's Sydney Morning Herald-this is a Labor member in a marginal seat in Brisbane-as saying: I believe that if we do not act to protect the interests. of thousands of home buyers who have taken out building society loans, we will be guilty of an error of mammoth proportions from which we as a Government, and home buyers may not recover. Mrs Darling says: The reality we face is that thousands of couples who have budgeted to their last cent in order to buy a modest home through a building society and who have already had their resources strained to the limit by four increases in repayments over the last year . . . will now face further increases as a result of lifting the ceiling on bank rates. She goes on to say: . . . many building society borrowers were paying about $620 a month on $50,000 loans over 30 years, and had seen repaymc;nts increase by $60 a month since January. This is not what I am saying; it is what a member from a marginal Government seat in Brisbane is saying. If 1 had time 1 would also refer to what was said by the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) from Western Australia, who is listed to speak tonight. He said similar things two weeks ago, just before the Prime Minister gave him the reassurance that the honourable member wanted. The honourable member and his constituents were cheated by the Prime Minister. It is awfuny lonely in a marginal seat like Stirling when one is led by a man whose word cannot be trusted. No one can ever trust the Prime Minister or the Treasurer again. Like the Australian donar under the Prime Minister's administration, his word is devalued. The main problem is that this Government has failed to produce the economic policies to reduce high interest rates. The Treasurer, like an arsonist who has started a fire, has come into join the fire brigade to put out the fire in the outhouse, leaving the house itself to burn. The Government, through its economic policies, has failed to reduce interest rates and failed to attack. the main part of the problem. It has let down ordinary householders throughout Australia. .

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION
text: I move: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Treasurer forthwith responding to the matter of public importance raised by the honourable member for Mackel\ar and directly relating to the high interest rate policies of the Govern-ent, that being a matter entirely within the Treasurer's portfolio responsibility. The Government. tonight has shown absolute contempt for every ordinary Australian. Today we had 300 farmers, in dire straits, outside this House. Why? Because the cruelling policies of this Government are grinding them into the dust. We have 500,000 Australians who have borrowed from building societies. Why? Because they thought that the Government meant its word when it said that interest rate ceilings would be maintained. This Government has decided that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will not come into the House to respond to debate on a policy for which he is directly responsible. Whether we are talking about small businessmen, the average home owner or the farmer, it is the Treasurer who has responsibility. It was the Treasurer who tonight during Question Time refused to allow the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) to respond to a question from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton); it was the Treasurer who said that it was his responsibility. But when it comes to an opportunity to respond to a matter raised by the shadow Treasurer, when it comes to the shadow Treasurer laying down the ground rules and showing that the Treasurer has misled the Parliament and the people of Australia and has culpably tried to beguile people into thinking that high interest rates are okay, the Treasurer does not bother to come into this place to respond. It is essential that Standing Orders be suspended so that those ordinary Australians can hear from the Treasurer why he has misled them and why they are being called on to pay higher and higher interest rates. Australia is going broke and the Treasurer is leading them in that direction. It is the Treasurer and the Treasurer alone who should come into this place to answer the shadow Treasurer. The honourable member for Mackellar was talking about average Australians, about the average family investing its savings. He was talking about a policy of high interest rates that this Treasurer has introduced into the House, for which this Treasurer is responsible and in respect of which the media is saying what a good fellow he is. Yet, the Treasurer is not even prepared to come into the Parliament and answer to his cause. It is not good enough that a junior Minister, albeit one who is assisting in the portfolio, should respond in an area in respect of which even at Question Time the Treasurer said: 'But I cannot let the Minister for Housing and Construction answer a question-it is too hard. We all saw the mess he made of it'. The Treasurer got up and said: 'I have to respond'. It is impossible for the people of Australia to have any confidence in the policies of a government which insists on passing the buck. We want the organ grinder, not the monkey. We want the man who is responsible. We do not want the fellow who is out there playing at the end of the string. This is far too serious a matter for the average Australian. Farmers, small businessmen and home owners have been misled by this Government. They are the people who are suffering. They are essentially the people who have been affected by the promises which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer have broken. Yet, the Treasurer will not come into the House to defend what he has done. Mr Deputy Speaker, it is essential that the man who is responsible for this policy should be in this House tonight to answer. It is interesting that the Prime Minister is not here. It is interesting to note that at this moment, this matter having been canvassed in the way it has, five members of the Australian Labor Party are in the chamber and that these members are totally incapable of responding to this matter. We know what happened in the Labor Caucus. We know how the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) feels on the issue. We know how the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) feels on the issue. We know how the people of Australia feel on this issue. Yet, the Government says: 'Oh, don't worry'. We know that the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) is not prepared to accept this Government's policy. Twenty-eight members of the Caucus moved a motion of no confidence in the Government today. It is a great government that is not prepared to come into the Parliament and answer its cause. What is happening, of course, is that the responsible Ministers are just running away from it all. They have passed the buck. They are not prepared to tell anyone why high interest rates will continue. They will not tell us why the dollar was allowed to float. They will not tell us about the increase in overseas debt. They will not tell us about the effect of the drought in the bush. They will not talk about the fact that everyone of us who has been falsely led into the belief that living standards will be maintained is being progressively screwed because of the economic policies of the Treasurer who has run for cover and who is not prepared to come into this House and respond to the charges properly made and laid by the shadow Treasurer. Tonight the shadow Treasurer laid down a list of sins and ills for economic disaster in this country. He laid down a cause for the average Australian. It is interesting that the Government no longer is prepared to tell average Australians what it is going to do. The average Australian knows that he cannot trust the Prime Minister. He knows that he can no longer trust the Treasurer. Every Australian knows that he cannot believe the Minister for Housing and Construction. Every Australian knows that when the monkey comes into the House and the organ grinder stays at home, what we are getting is not the real story but a little bit of a subterfuge. We are being told: 'Just tell everybody that everything is all right. We will play the issue down. Don't worry about interest rates. Don't worry about the people of Australia. We read the polls a few weeks ago and we think we will be all right'. The Government should ask members in marginal seats what they think. It should ask the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) who knows that he will lose his seat the next time round. It should ask the honourable member for Lilley, who is not in the chamber, what she thinks about the Treasurer's economic policy. What has happened in Australia is that the Treasurer

Title: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION
text: That is right. She is probably on the phone or talk back. The whole point of this debate tonight is that the Government has shown it neither has the answers nor the integrity to respond to a matter. of high economic principle. It is not sufficient for this Parliament to be treated with contempt by the Treasurer. He can run away and say: 'Oh, it does not matter. Look, I am too good for that place. I'll go off in my Ferrari and I'll look at my antiques and my clocks and I won't worry about little Australians'. I have a word for the Treasurer. He needs to understand that the average Australian at the moment is worrying about bread and butter. The average farmer is looking at a level of income whereby many of them will run into essentially losses of more than $20,000. The interest bill on rural debt this year will be greater than the total farm income. It is in that climate that the Treasurer says: 'I am not going to worry about farmers'. One has only to look at small businessmen, who have been forced to layoff employees, or at the housing area where one has building societies which, we are told, are a lesser breed. The banks get a $120m subsidy. What about the building societies? We heard the Minister for Housing and Construction tonight say: 'It is a State matter-never mind about us'. Frank Walker, the Minister for Housing in New South Wales, has a few views on that topic. ThGovernment in Queensland has a few views on the matter, too. The point is that this matter deserves to be treated with respect, the people of Australia deserve to be treated with respect. The home owners, the home loan borrowers, the small businessmen, the farmers, average Australians deserve to be treated with respect. When the Treasurer and all the members of the Labor Party say 'Never mind about home owners, never mind about interest rates', I can tell them that that is exactly the attitude the electors of Australia will have to the Government. If the Government is prepared to treat in this way the most serious and fundamental crisis and economic management which this country has faced under this disaster who is the Treasurer, we shall be in a position where we cannot any longer sustain our standard of living. The accord will go. The shadow Treasurer tonight has laid down a case which is unanswerable. It is the responsibility of the Treasurer to come into this House and respond, and we on this side of the House are not going to stop disrupting the affairs of the Government until it is prepared to treat this House and the people of Australia with the respect that they deserve.

Speaker: Mr NA BROWN
Title: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION
text: 1 second this motion, and I do so because the House is entitled to hear from the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-not from a junior Minister, albeit a junior Minister who has some responsibility in this field. We believe that the matters raised in this matter of public importance are of such overwhelming importance and contain such an indictment of the Government that there is only one proper way for the Government to respond, and that is by having the Treasurer contribute to the debate. We say that because this matter is of extraordinary importance. We have drawn attention to: The fear, worry and insecurity created in countless Australian families by the Government's high interest rate policies and its confused and inequitable actions on home loans. If there ever were an issue that went directly to the responsibility of the Treasurer personally, it must be this matter. Interest rates are the responsibility of the Treasurer, and the effect on the economy, on small business people and on farmers of those home interest rate policies, of interest rate policies in general, of economic policies in general, are directly and personally the responsibility of the Treasurer. If this Government has an ounce of responsibility towards this Parliament, it will produce the Treasurer from his funkhole or wherever he is and get him in here to contribute to the debate and reply to the allegations which have been made against him by the shadow Treasurer. Why is the Treasurer not here? He is full of bravado at Question Time. He is very happy to throw words around and smear people whenever he has the opportunity of doing so, but when it comes to making a speech on major matters of economic policy, where is he? He is missing. He must be, out at an auction of antique clocks or buying a new car or something. Why is he not here to respond to these allegations? This is where he should be and it is up to .the Government to produce him. We believe iUs important because the Treasurer is responsible for these matters. The Treasurer-let us pause and think about this simple fact-came here to the Parliament, where a person's word is supposed to be above reproach, only a matter of days ago, in the last two-week sitting, and said: 'I will not taking to the Cabinet a submission suggesting or proposing that the interest rate ceiling will be lifted'. He said he would not do that. When he made that statement he had before him all the facts that he has before him now. Yet he was prepared to stand up in the Parliament and say that he would not take such a submission to Cabinet. What did he do as soon as the Parliament got up? He did exactly the opposite. He went off to try to save his skin and the skin of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) by producing to the Cabinet the very submission that he had said in this Parliament he would not produce. How can one take the word of the Treasurer when that is what he has said? How can one take the word of the Prime Minister when he has said virtually the same thing? One cannot take him at his word. If the Treasurer has an ounce of decency he should come in here now and explain the economic policies of the Government. He should explain why there was an extraordinary turnaround in events in a matter of a few days. He should explain how small business people will survive with high interest rates. He should explain how rural industries will survive with high interest rates. He should give the people some sort of hope for the future that this Government has at least a modicum of knowledge about what is going on with regard to the economy. There is a double obligation on the Treasurer to do this because it is not simply a matter of broken promises on interest rates. Let us think of some of those momentous remarks made by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister over the last few months. Who can forget the memorable statement: 'There will be no capital gains tax'? That-promise was broken. We were told that interest rates would come ' down. That promise was broken. We were told that inflation would come down. What utter nonsense. That was a completely baseless promise. The young unemployed of this country were promised 10,000 traineeships under the Priority One program. How many have been producedone, two, 10, 100 or 200? It is about time that members of the Government answered some of those questions. It is about time that they exercisedsome of their responsibility. It is about time that they came into this Parliament and defended their policies. Above all, it is about time they got the Treasurer to defend their hopeless economic position.

Speaker: Mr YOUNG
Title: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION
text: First of all, 1 congratulate the right honourable member for New England (Mr be Sinclair) for his outstanding example of how to use the Parliament. He was giving the worse speech this Parliament has heard for decades and the right honourable member for New England said to himself: 'How can 1 save the situation? What should I do to give our team a lift? We can't go on like this because the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) will slay him when he gets up, so we have to stop this'. The poor old honourable member for Mackellar was drivelling on about what the Opposition would do and even honourable me'!lbers opposite were not listening to him, so the fight honourable member for New England had to save the situation. I say to him: Congratulations. It was a good tactic, and if 1 had not been here it would have worked. Honourable members opposite have been away from the House for 19 days. I ask those honourable members opposite who asked the Treasurer a question just an hour ago to put up their hands. Who asked the Treasurer a question? No one did. There are 60 honourable members sitting opposite. They were given 4S minutes of Question Time and they did not even have a question to ask of the Treasurer. That ,shows how good they are. Not even one question was asked. The Leader of the Opposition has been away from here for 19 days and he could not even ask the Treasurer a question. Yet honourable members opposite now say that the Treasurer has to come into this chamber to speak. Let me remind honourable members opposite of what used to happen when the late Sir Phillip Lynch was the Treasurer and the shadow Treasurer proposed a matter of public importance. Do honourable members know who used to be sent in and who used to come trundling in smiling because he had got this big job? The honourable member for Bennelong used to be given the job for the late Sir Phillip Lynch when he was Treasurer. Without checking the records, J think that the Treasurer of this Government has responded to more matters of public importance on these questions than any Treasurer previously. When I came into the House and sat down, I thought: 'Paul, you will get lots of questions tonight. They have been away. They are frisky. They have been waiting for 19 days. If an honourable member is north of the Victorian border, he is okay; if he is south or west of the Victorian border, he is no good at all, and John Valder will get rid of him. They must not stand up against the majority decisions. This once great party, the Liberal Party, used to let everybody have his say and vote as he liked. That was always the way with Menzies, if one looks at his record. He did not mind how people voted; he just sent them overseas for the rest of their lives. This great tradition of the Liberal Party is going to be reimposed by John Va1der. Mr Carlton-I rise on a point of order. The Minister has not yet mentioned building society interest rates.

I went to some lengths to outline the considerable steps which this Government had taken since coming to office to deal within the established industrial relations framework with the problems posed by the BLF. However, efforts by the Government, employers and the trade union movement to achieve a permanent resolution to the problems were repudiated at every PAIRS turn by the BLF. It was against this background and the immense damage being done not only to the industry, but also to the job security of building workers, by the actions of the BLF that the Government decided it had no alternative ADJOURNMENT but to pursue the course of action set out in the Building Industry Bill. Accordingly, following· the passage of the Building Industry Act, I applied on 6 September 1985 to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for a declaration under the Act. I sought a declaration that the BLF had engaged in conduct which contravened agreements or undertakings to which it was a party, which seriously hindered or prevented the achievement of objects of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act or which was inimical to the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes by conciliation and arbitration. In short the Full Bench was asked to consider whether the BLF had engaged in conduct which threatened the very basis of our present system of industrial relations. My application was duly dealt with by a Full Bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which handed down its decision last Friday. r should add that the Government's application was supported by the Governments of New South Wales and Victoria, by the Confederation of Australian Industry and by building employers through the Australian Confederation of Construction Contractors and the Master Builders Federation of Australia. This support for the Government's application emphasises the extent of concern within the community at the behaviour of the BLF and the damage its actions have inflicted on the building industry and on the economy. Because of the serious consequences of the action under the Building Industry Act the Government was most concerned that the Builders Labourers Federation should receive every opportunity to know in detail what the Government alleged against it and to answer those allegations. The Act made such provision and there were extensive proceedings before the Commission. These proceedings occupied 56 sitting days and covered 4,500 pages of transcript. Counsel representing the Government tendered 298 exhibits to demonstrate to the Full Bench that the BLF's conduct was such as to warrant the making of a declaration. The BLF itself tendered 105 exhibits, was represented by four counsel-including two Queen's Counsel and called 75 witnesses and evidence from all States, including the Australian Capital Territory. On 4 April, the Full Bench issued the declaration which the Government had sought. In doing so, the Full Bench concluded that: It has been established beyond question that the Builders Labourers Federation has rejected the standards of behaviour accepted by most trade unions in Australia. The Federation has no standards is commonly understood, but reacts to events according to the view taken at the time by the Federal Management Committee. Instead of a rational policy designed to advance the interests of the members, the Federal Management Committee is addicted to slogans. The Full Bench went on to say: It is under such archaic banners that the Federal Management Committee has waged its campaigns, leading the rank and file from one disaster to the next. The efforts of the leaders have caused hardship to other workers and aroused the hostility of the other building unions. Builders labourers have been deprived of national wage case increases until long after other Australian workers have received that benefit; the excesses of the leadership have taken the Federation so far outside conventional trade union activity that it has been expelled by the Labour Council of New South \:Vales. As our review of the evidence has shown, the activities of the Federation have brought extensive dislocation to the building industry. The case against the Builders Labourers Federation is overwhelming. The declaration made by the Full Bench illustrates the breadth of the Federation's disregard for normal standards of industrial behaviour. The declaration specifies numerous fundamental breaches by the BLF of agreements and undertakings regarding its conduct within the Federal system. These include breaches of undertakings the BLF gave to the Industrial Registrar, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, employers and of industry agreements. Those breaches were the result of many instances of extremely damaging industrial action which led the Full Bench to declare that the BLF had prevented or seriously hindered the achievement of objects of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and had engaged in conduct that was inimical to the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes by means of conciliation and arbitration. Even while the hearing was before the Commission, the union showed its complete contempt for the Commission, and its disregard for its undertakings, by pursuing claims that were patently in breach of the national wage principles and by backing those claims with widespread industrial action. The consequences of that action were very serious indeed. For example, many building sites in every Australian State have been affected by strikes, bans and threats in pursuit of claims for the 3.8 per cent national wage increase, other wage claims, implementation of a shorter working week and payment for time on strike. As a consequence of these actions major projects have been held up and fellow building workers have been stood down and as that word their livelihood jeopardised. The BLF, by its actions during and immediately after the hearing, has led the Government to the view that immediate measures are needed so that the Federation should no longer remain a registered organisation. The Federation has continued to flout every accepted convention on which the Australian system of industrial relations depends and its guerilla tactics, industrial blackmail and intimidation are an anathema to the vast majority of trade unionists. A clear illustration of the BLF's total contempt for the system is seen from the fact that on the very day that the Full Bench's decision was handed down, more than 100 sites in New South Wales and Victoria alone were subject to bans in support of various BLF claims with no regard to the normal processes of ment through conciliation and arbitration. The Government cannot allow the threat to the Australian conciliation and arbitration system, to the building industry and to its workers posed by the behaviour of the BLF to continue. It cannot allow one organisation to disregard utterly the accepted processes of dispute ment and prevent the establishment of a strong, efficient building industry which can make a major contribution to economic and employment growth in Australia. The stage has now been reached where: After a very lengthy hearing, the ConciliaConciliation tion and Arbitration Commission has made a declaration based on a careful and thorough examination of the evidence before it. That decision is a damning indictment of the BLF's behaviour; Time and time again, the BLF has shown it will not mend its ways and that it has no respect for the processes of conciliation and arbitration or the system which enables it to enjoy the status and benefits of a registered organisation; The BLF has lost the support of the trade union movement as a whole; The building industry continues to be seriously disrupted by the BLF's industrial action and faces the prospect of further sustained attack; and The system itself continues to be under rious challenge. The union is clearly only interested in using every available avenue to threaten, intimidate, coerce and weaken the resolve of all those engaged in the building industry to resist unreasonwhich able demands by the BLF while it remains registered and enjoys the privileges and protection of the system. In these circumstances the Government has decided that the only responsible course is to immediately cancel the registration of the Federation. This means that the BLF will no longer be a registered organisation under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act anywhere in Australia. The Bill I have now introduced will have that effect. Without immediate action, the BLF will undoubtedly do everything in its power to string out for many months final resolution of proceedings under the Building Industry Act in relation to it and, at the same time, place massive industrial pressure on employers not to support the dispute settle- Government's action. The BLF has no right to the protection of the system whilst at the same time it seems intent on destroying the system. Registration under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act does not confer only rights and privileges but also involves obligations to behave responsibly and in a manner settle- consistent with the objects of the Act. I must emphasise that the action which this Government has already taken in relation to the BLF and what is proposed now is not intended as an attack on ordinary builders labourers. It is the leadership of the Federation which cannot be trusted and which, as the Full Bench of the and Arbitration Commission said, has led the rank and file from one disaster to another. . The Government will be concerned to ensure that the jobs and conditions of individual labourers are protected and that they are able to join appropriate federally registered unions with coverage of their work and which will properly represent their interests. It is essential in the interests of the workers concerned and the system of conciliation and arbitration that they should be able to be represented and enjoy the protection of their conditions of employment by awards and agreements secured under that system. Employers will have a vital role to play under the new arrangements. They will have to ensure that the rights of labourers prepared to work normally are maintained. In addition, builders sewill have to be prepared to stand firm against efforts of the BLF to maintain its place in the industry. The Government will be looking to employers to remain united in support of our action. I should add that the code of conduct to the employers are required to adhere will be maintained and any employer seeking to deal with the deregistered BLF will risk exclusion from government contracts. Furthermore, should it prove to be necessary, the Government, with the co-operation of the State governments, stands ready to ensure the maintenance of order so that workers wanting to get on with their jobs in the industry will be able to do so without interference, threat or coercion. The terms of this Bill are simple. Honourable members will note that its preamble places emphasis on the public interest in preserving the system of conciliation and arbitration. The proceedings before the Commission, the Commission's findings, and the BLF's continuing misconduct demonstrate conclusively how serious a threat to that system the BLF has bee!!. Flowing from that and from the concerns I have expressed, the Bill goes on to declare, that, upon its becoming law, the registration of the BLF will forthwith be cancelled. This is a step which the Government is taking as a last resort and after the Government has shown great forbearance and patience in exploring all reasonable alternatives. However, the BLF has shunned every effort to resolve this matter within the established industrial relations processes and has alienated itself from virtually all other groups within the community, including the trade union movement. The BLF's activities have been condemned by other building unions, led to its expulsion from the New South Wales Trades and Labour Council and caused the Australian Council of Trade Unions to declare that it cannot support the BLF. The circumstances confronting us are therefore unique in the history of the nation and they require a unique solution. It is in that context· that the Government has decided to take the serious action contained in this Bill. Such action is essential to preserve the future of the building industry, to establish rational industrial relations behaviour in that industry, to protect the national wage fixing principles and to preserve the authority of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Most of all, this legislation is essential to secure the preservation of the federal system of prevention and settlement of industrial disputes by conciliation and arbitration. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. Debate (on motion by Mr N. A. Brown) adjourned. Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Title: BUILDERS LABOURERS FEDERATION
text: ,--I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. I have in my second reading speech on the Builders Labourers' Federation (Cancellation of Regi-tration) Bill 1986 explained why the Government has decided to take action which will result in the immediate de-registration of the Federation as a registered organisation under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The Bill which deals with· three important areas that are consequential upon the cancellation of the Federation's registration is expressed to come into operation when that occurs. These areas relate firstly to the consequences of the Federation's deregistration, secondly, to the question of the registration in the future of the Federation or a similar body, and thirdly, to the coverage by federally registered unions of work which was covered by the Federation before the cancellation of its registration. I shall address each of these areas in turn. Clause 4 of the Bill provides for the consequences of the Federation's deregistration. Important elements of this provision relate to operation of awards and access to the federal conciliation and arbitration machinery. It provides that no award applying to the Federation or its members will .have any force or effect in relation to them. The clause also provides that the deregistered Federation, .or any association of members or former members of the Federation formed in relation to the building industry, will not be able to participate in proceedings before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission or be a Party to an award made by tile Commission. Furthermore, the Com1Dission will not. have jurisdiction over industrial disputes brought about by such bodies or their members, or by employers who are in diSpute with them. The provision makes it clear, however,. that the Co-missioh is not denied jurisdiction over disputes between an employer and a registered union in relation to any of its members who may not have relinquished their membership of the Federation or of some other association in the industry formed by the members or former members of the Federation. This is necessary so that Federation members who join registered unions before they cease, to be members of the Federation have access to the federal dispute settlement procedures and awards as members of such registered unions. The second significant area of the Bill concerns the future registration of the Federation. The Government believes that it would be entirely inappropriate for the Federation to be able to re-apply for registration immediately after its registration has been cancelled. Honourable members need reflect only on the Federation's conduct after it was registered again in 1976 after being deregistered in 1974. Despite undertakings about its industrial behaviour and adherence to the process of conciliation and arbitration, it demonstrated within months of reregistration that it had no intention of abiding by those undertakings. Its subsequent conduct showed how little the obligations of a registered union meant to it. I refer honourable members to last week's decision of the Full Bench of the Commission to make a declaration under the Building Industry Act for a clear ex.position of the appalling his, tory of the Federation's conduct after it was so reregistered. The Government therefore believes that a reasonable period should be set before the Federation can apply to be registered again. We consider that three years is the minimum period in which stability can be restored to the building industry without the presence of the Federation as a federally registered union. Such a period is provided for in clause 5. Furthermore, the Government believes that the Federation should not be capable of registration again unless it is prepared to behave responsibly as a registered organisation. Accordingly, Clause 5 also contains a requirement that a Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission must be satisfied that the Federation would not, if registered, engage in conduct inimical to the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes by means of conciliation and arbitration, and that such registration would not prevent or seriously hinder' the achievement of an object of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The other requirements of the ConciliatioTl and Arbitration Act as to registration will also apply, but any application for registration must also be dealt with by a Full Bench. These requirements also extend to any association formed in the industry by members or former members of the Federation. This will prevent any attempt to sidestep the requirements as to registration. The third important area of the proposed legislation relates to arrangements for federally registered unions to cover work of which the BLF had cove-age when registered. Clause 7 provides that regulations may be made to give federally registered unions coverage of work in the industry in or in connection with which the Federation was registered. This can be done only with the consent of those unions. The regulations will deClare persons who work in that industry to be eligible for membership of the consenting union. Such regulations may relate to work of specified kind in the industry or part of the industry, and in Australia generally or specified parts of Australia. This is considered an essential measure to provide industrial peace in the industry, and to ensure that' workers who are or were members of the Federation are able to be represented by responsible' registered unions, to have disputes over their employment settled through the proper processes of conciliation and arbitration and to secure the protection of federal awards. I wish to emphasise that no union will be compelled to accept an extension of its existing work coverage and the Government will be consulting fully with all interested parties to ensure that the most appropriate arrangements are made. It is not our intention that these arrangements should result in disruption to the existing work' coverage of any federally registered unions. Another important aspect of clause 7 is that these arrangements are intended to be of an interim nature until federally registered unions cart alter their rules to cover such work. The regulations will therefore cease to operate to the extent that they are not consistent with any subsequent rule alterations made under the processes ,of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Madam Speaker, each of these elements of the Bill represents an important part of the Government's approach to securing the proper operation of the federal system of dispute settlement, and the achievement of better industrial relations in the building industry. I stress that this cannot be achieved without the best efforts of employers, unions and workers in that industry to strive for a permanent improvement in their industrial relationships. Australia cannot afford to continue to have a situation like that brought about by the BLF. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. NA Assets Test- Mrs Dorothy Saunders-Home Heating Oil Prices-Film Processing Motion (by Mr Willis) proposed: That the House do now adjourn.  week the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) at my invitation visited the Mallee electorate. This visit allowed him to see the human face of the effects of the rural crisis and the impact of the Government's assets test on pensioners. Most of what I am about to say was included in the submission presented to the Minister by the Women in Agriculture group from Sea Lake. In order to understand fully the predicament of so many of the elderly people affected by the assets test it is necessary to have a measure at least of the people themselves, who have taken pride in the fact that they have never received government welfare assistance of any nature. Our present day elderly, in line with the above, have been steeped in the work ethic and have taken pride in their independence. In earlier times this pride was a survival kit enabling them to overcome heart breaking difficulties, but it is now one of their biggest liabilities. Many have continued to work their farms until they are physically no longer able to do so. Of course, age has very little to do with it. They llll like feel that they are in control of their own destiny. Whether eventually they transferred the land to the next generation, willed it to the next generation or sold it was an individual decision. One way or another they anticipated that the farms would provide them with an income for life. Now they are trapped, because the world they knew and understood and in which they are competent no longer exists. It is being destroyed by high interest rates, high domestic costs, low commodity returns and no warning of the Government's attack upon thrift and capital through its attack upon the hard-earned assets of generations. It may not have mattered how much information the Government gave to the public prior to the introduction of the assets test. These people, in effect, would have said: 'That's got nothing to do with me'. This is not a reflection upon their intelligence but an indication of their psychological response to life. Into this scenario has come the rural economic crisis and in the central Mallee area as well a succession of poor seasons. Mr Tim Fischer-Soldier settlers have been hit particularly hard.  Marketing settlers have been hit as well. The land, their asset, which in theory was to provide them with an income, is now useless for this purpose. Their traditional survival kit, a tightening of the belt, will no longer work. The cost structure under which the contemporary wheat industry operates is now outside their life experience. Those who made the personal decision years ago to transfer the land to the next generation and therefore retain only personal assets have been able in this rural crisis to apply for and receive the' age pension without difficulty. Others who made the personal decision to retain the land in their name until some future date find themselves in the same financial position as those I have mentioned and have been caught by the assets test. The elderly in the second category have been living on their now dwindling savings or on their children's bank overdrafts, sometimes using their savings to prop up the ailing farm business. If in desperation they apply for the age pension, under· the requirements of the assets test they hit what seems to them to be a solid brick wall in the form first of all of being required to have their land revalued which, in effect, means devalued-a frightening and unrealistic requirement given the crisis to in the whole industry. Then follows the implementation of the 2+ per cent deemable income clause, when the property is now returning a negative income. The hardship clause requires proof that that asset is producing little or no income and also that these people are unable to sell, lease or borrow against it. Finally, there is the pensions loans scheme, which is better known as the pay as you die scheine. In order that the present generation might continue their employment in the industry, the older people have no option but to use their asset as collateral to maintain the viability of the farm in today's conditions. The above fact explains the inability of the elderly to sell or borrow further against the asset or to apply for the pensions loans scheme, since to do so would destroy the present employment of their· children. The practicalities involved in an application for the age pension against the background of the assets test are these: While the brochures of the Department of Social Security give the impression that it is a relatively simple procedure, in practice it involves numerous interviews to set the review process in train and then months of waiting for the decision. It appears that decisions cannot be made at a regional level, but must be made in Melbourne or Canberra. Appeals cannot be made to the Tribunal until the results of the review are known. This applies to a whole class of people, not just one or two individuals. Bearing in mind that this class of people may be aged anywhere between 65 to 85 years plus, it is no wonder that they find it to be a daunting, frightening procedure in which they see them-. selves in the position of peasants appealing to the Government for help. Given the aforementioned traditional pride, very few, even in cult circumstances, are prepared to use the appeals system to its fullest. The Minister for Social Security must modify the assets test if he is not prepared to abolish it.

Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Dorothy Elizabeth Jean Saunders was 76 years old a few months ago. Although she is not known to this House, she was an identity in the goldfields. She was born and bred in the goldfields. She came from a family of eight children. She grew up in Kalgoorlie, went to North Kalgoorlie Primary School and then to the Eastern Goldfields District High School. She worked for many years for legal firms in Kalgoorlie. During the war she served in the legal corps of the Army. She then joined the Eastern Goldfields Technical School, where she taught commercial studies to generations of goldfields girls. She was the deputy and then head of that school for many years. Dorothy Saunders was involved in numei:ous community activities. She was secretary of the Paraplegic Society for years. She was past president of the Golden Mile Art Group and a member of Meals on Wheels, whose meals she kept on delivering until a few months ago despite the fact that for some time she was not in the best of health. She was a regular Friend of the Hospital. She should have been citizen of the year for many years, but it was an honour she never sought and in truth would not have considered herself worthy of, for she never wanted any limelight. She helped numerous people financially and otherwise and was a tower of strength to people in need, emotionally and in other ways. One of her loves was music and she conducted the St John's Choir for many years. In 1975 she was the driving force behind the production of the Messiah in the goldfields, a production which is still talked about today. She was very involved with the Anglican church in the goldfields. A couple or years ago she compiled a history of the church which is quite a scholarly document. 'Saundy', as she was affectionately known by people in the goldfields, was a Christian. I am not a Christian and I have a very jaundiced and cynical view of most religions, but in her case she lived her religion by her everyday example, by the kindness and compassion that she brought to living. Today she was buried in Kalgoorlie. She is survived by a brother, Charles, in Sydney, a sister, Joan, in Tasmania, and two brothers, diffi- Syd and Norm, in Perth, to whom I send my condolences. She was my neighbour and she was a de facto grandmother to my children. I have two children, Ainsley and Leyland, who have no grandparents of their own. They loved her deeply and she loved them. Kalgoorlie knows what it has lost in the death of 'Saundy', but the world has lost too, for people like 'Saundy' are very rare and hard to find.

text: 1 offer my condolences to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), who is obviously very moved by such a sad loss. There have been many farmers arouqd here today and I sympathise with them, especially in regard to the price of fuel. I also sympathise with the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew),  Fisher) and the honourable member for Wannon acting (Mr Hawker), who have been in the House tonight, because they represent rural electorates. The thing I have not against the governments but against the oil companies concerns home heating oil. During the boom, before Australia went to import parity pricing, everybody installed home oil heaters. In the. cooler climates of Tasmania, Victoria and South Australia everybody put in an oil heater, but as soon as we went to import parity pricing-I do not have time to talk about that-the price of home heating oil went up astronomically. The peaks in price always commence in the winter, when most people need their home heating oil. I am absolutely staggered to find that in Tasmania, instead of coming down, the price of home heating oil has gone up. The further I checked the more intrigued I became with this commodity. The Prices Surveillance Authority, which recommends a maximum wholesale price for most petroleum products, does not recommend any price for home heating oil. The regrettable thing is that the oil companies know this. Their feed stock has gone down and there has been a reduction in the price of oil. The price of a barrel of imported oil at the moment is the lowest it has been for eight years. The price of home heating oil to the pensioners, to the ordinary people and to the farmers of Australia should have come down, but instead it has gone up. It is 54.5c a litre in Hobart at the moment, which is the same as petrol. That is outrageous. I have written to the responsible Minister in a nice, sensible way saying that he should have a good look at it. It is absolutely wrong that the price should go up when we are coming into the peak time, when heating oil is most needed in the cooler climates of Tasmania and Victoria, where 90 per cent of home heating oil is consumed. It needs to be far cheaper; after all, it is only a by-product. The oil companies use the argument that they have been losing on fuel prices and they need to make it up on home heating oil. That is wrong. After that serious matter I would like to get on to something light-hearted. Today I was staggered. I have always followed marketing and the activities of the airlines. One often sits in the plane, twiddles one's thumbs and thinks about how the airlines make a buck. I saw today the classic example. I flew with Trans Australia Airlines from Hobart and I had a bit of time to think. I was looking at the packets in the compartment where they put their booklets and so forth and I saw this little packet labelled 'Leisure Photos'. The packet stated: Save up to 65% on your holiday photos. The address was Freepost No.4, Leisure Photos, P.O. Box 100, Turramurra, New South Wales, 2074. It continued: Relive those wonderful memories from only $3.99. This meant that, if one has a film, the film can be put in the packet and sent off. Then I saw: Should you feel ill during the flight, please use this bag. So it is an air sickness bag! People can either put their films in it or other things. I thought that was a classic. Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Title: AUSTRALIAN OVERSEAS PROJECTS CORPORATION
text: The answer to the honourable member's question, based on information provided by the Human Rights Commission, is as follows: (I) (a) The full-time equivalent of officers involved in processing (as distinct from conciliating) complaints of breaches of human rights under the Human Rights Commission Act 1981 in offices of the Human Rights Commission is as follows: Canberra 1.9, Brisbane O. L (b) The full-time equivalent of officers involved in conciliating alleged breaches of human rights under the Human Rights Commission Act 1981 in offices of the Human Rights Commission is as follows: Canberra 2, Brisbane 0.25. These figures relate only to the processing and conciliation of complaints under the Human Rights Commission Act 1981 in offices of the Commission. Under cooperative arrangements with Victoria, New South Wales, South Australia and Western Australia, complaints under that Act are being handled by State human rights and equal opportunity bodies. (2) During the period \0 December 1981 to 30 June 1985 there were 874 complaints of alleged breaches of human rights under the Human Rights Commission Act 1981 received by the Human Rights Commission. Of these, 393 complaints were outside jurisdiction, leaving 481 for inquiry and attempted settlement and conciliation under the Human Rights Commission Act 1981. (3) During the period 10 December 1981 to 30 June 1985, of the 481 complaints accepted under the Human Rights Commission Act 1981, (a) 216 matters were withdrawn before conciliation; (b) 202 matters were conciliated and settled; and (c) 63 matters were in the process of conciliation by the Commission. Combined Air-Road-Rail Packages (Question No. 2960) Mr Tickner asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 November 1985: What action has been taken by the Commonwealth to encourage the introduction of combined air-rail-road passenger fares.  able member's question is as follows: Although the Federal Government has no direct control over the fares offered by transport operators I have encouraged all operators to continue to offer appropriate package arrangements where it is in their interest to do so. I am advised that the Australian National Railways Commission has, within the forum of the Railways of Australia Committee, proposed that a combined ticket covering air, rail and bus travel be investigated. This matter is being progressed through that Committee. The legislative arrangements governing domestic aviation were introduced by the previous Government in 1981 and provide for the formulation and development of new fare initiatives, including conditions attached to a fare, as matters for the airlines based on their own commercial judgment. Fare proposals must then be submitted to the Independent Air Fares Committee (IAFC) and be approved by the Committee before they can be offered to the pUblic. The Government places a high priority on encouraging the airlines to introduce new fare initiatives in order to make air travel available to a wider cross-section of the public and improve tourist potential throughout Australia. The domestic airlines introduced 'Air Pass' discount fares in 1983, These fares were specifically aimed at the domestic and international tourist markets and are designed to offer the traveller greater flexibility in. the arrangement of tours around Australia. A major advantage of these fare types is their availability to travellers at a known price without restrictions . as to time of day or date, Passengers are basically free to choose their own itineraries within maximum distance and stopover limitations.. As the origin and destination of travel on 'Air Pass' tickets can be different, there would already appear to be scope for passengers to use this fare in conjunction with travel they wish to undertake on other modes. In 1984-85, $198,200 was allocated to ten projects relevant to the assessment of housing stock in parts of New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania. Broadcasting on the Inland Radio Transmitter (Question No. 3183) Mr Macphee asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 13 February 1986: (I) What are the terms and conditions of the agreement between the ABC and the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association (CAAMA) in relation to broadcasting on the Inland RadioYTransmitter System in the Northern Territory. (2) How many hours of broadcasting over the system does CAAMA engage in per week. (3) Are there any changes to the current arrangement between the ABC and CAAMA being contemplated.

Speaker: Mr DUFFY
Title: DHC DHC
text: Based on advice provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), the answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) The Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association (CAAMA) has been contracted by the ABC to provide programs for Aborigines in the service areas of two of the three HF Inland Radio Transmitters-VL8A Alice Springs and VL8T Tennant Creek. This contract has been entered in response to Recommendation 8 of the report of the Task Force on Aboriginal Broadcasting and Communications, presented to the House on 27 November 1985. The contract provides for CAAMA to broadcast programs in three Aboriginal Languages and English. Programs are broadcast from the CAAMA studio, via the ABC studio, overriding control being at the ABC's discretion. (2) CAAMA currently broadcasts 62 hours per week on the service, through Alice Springs. Tennant Creek transmitter is not yet operating. (3) Changes to the arrangement are contemplated and are subject to further study by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs/Department of Communications implementation group charged with the carriage of the Task Force recommendations. This study includes the possibility of legislative amendments to allow for mission sharing and alternative management arrangements for the HF Inland system. Proposed Visit to Taiwan Mr Braithwaite asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 14 February 1986: Did any officer of his Department have discussions with the Mayor of the Gold Coast Alderman Dennis Pie, regarding a trip he proposed making to Taiwan, if so: (a) What was the nature of the discussions, (b) what was the outcome of the discussions, (c) who was the officer involved, (d) on whose instructions was he or she operating, and (e) how did his Department become aware of Mr Pie's proposed trip.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: DHC DHC
text: The answer to the honourable System member's question is as follows: Yes. (a) The Department of Foreign Affairs' advice was sought by the Office of the Town Clerk, Gold Coast, concerning travel to Taiwan. The enquiry was in the context of a possible visit there, among other destinations, by the Mayor of the Gold Coast and several councillors. The Office of the Town Clerk was informed of Federal Government policy concerning non-recognition of Taiwan. It was noted that Federal public servants could only advise bodies such as local councils of Federal policy, as a factor to be taken into account in determining their own decisions. Other factors noted to the Town Clerk's Office as having a possible bearing on any decision to travel to Taiwan by a Mayoral delegation from the Gold Coast were the growing links between the Queensland Government and China and any interest the Gold Coast might have in developing its own relations in China. (b) It is understood thilt the Gold Coast delegation decided not to visit Taiwan. (c) The initial enquiry from the Town Clerk's Office was received on 28 January 1986, by an officer in the Department's Consular and Passports Branch and referred to the China/Korea Section. The Acting Head of that Section, Ms M. Marginson phoned the Town Clerk:s Office on 29 January to convey the views noted in (b) (d) As acting Section Head, Ms Marginson is familiar with Federal Government policy on relations with Taiwan and responsible for day to day inquiries which relate to it, and she was acting under the supervision of her immediately senior officer. (e) The Gold Coast Town Clerk's Office brought the visit to the Department's attention through its enquiries on 28 January 1986. Engine Reconditioning Industry (Question No. 3264) Mr Tickner asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 19 February 1986: Is the stability of the Australian engine reconditioning industry under threat from the rapid growth in imported used engines; if so, what action can be taken by the Minister's Department to ensure its stability pending a report being made by the Industries Assistance with the prices Commission. Mr Barry Jones-The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: The Government does not consider that the stability of the Australian engine reconditioning industry is under immediate threat from imported used engines. It did, however, consider that growth in imports could pose a threat in the future and accordingly referred the matter to the Industries Assistance Commission on 19 September 1985 for inquiry and report. In doing this it was concerned to ensure that the views of all interested parties be taken into consideration before a decision is taken on the future assistance arrangements for the industry. The lAC has advised that a draft report on the industry is expected to be released towards the end of April/early May.
